A ring \(R\) is called Noetherian if every ascending chain of ideals \(\mathfrak{a}_{1} \subset \mathfrak{a}_{2} \subset \ldots \subset R\) becomes stationary after finitely many steps, or equivalently, every ideal of \(R\) is finitely generated.

Given a commutative ring R, the polynomial ring R[X] is the set of all sequences (a_i) where a_i in R and a_i=0 for almost all i, equipped with addition and multiplication defined by (a_i)+(b_i)=(a_i+b_i) and (a_i) 
cdot (b_i)=(c_i) where c_i=
sum_{
u+
u=i} a_
u b_
u. Elements of R[X] can be written as 
sum_{i=0}^n a_i X^i where X is the sequence (0,1,0,0,...).
Does the concept of a/an Noetherian ring need to be defined for a definition of a/an Polynomial Ring to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The definition of a Polynomial Ring involves a commutative ring R and does not inherently require that R be Noetherian. The concept of a Polynomial Ring, R[X], is defined based on the elements of R and the operations of addition and multiplication of sequences, where these sequences represent polynomials. The definition specifies how to construct and manipulate these polynomials without any reference to the properties of the ideals of R, such as whether every ideal is finitely generated or not.\n\nOn the other hand, a Noetherian ring is defined by a property concerning its ideals, specifically that every ascending chain of ideals becomes stationary or every ideal is finitely generated. This property is not necessary to define the basic structure and operations of a polynomial ring. Therefore, the concept of a Noetherian ring is not required for the definition of a Polynomial Ring to make sense. The Polynomial Ring can be defined and understood entirely independently of whether the ring R is Noetherian.
